prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Based on previous observations of HCO+ absorption, we expect the detected linewidths to be ~1-4 km/s. Therefore, we request 0.2 km/s resolution to make sure that the narrowest expected lines are well-resolved by at least 4 resolution elements.

All proposed targets are known ALMA calibrators (point sources), which we require to be unresolved for absorption measurements. We allow for angular resoultion up to 3 arcseconds in order to make sure that the sources are unresolved, but also to allow for some compact array configurations to be used to conduct the observations.

Our requested rms is driven by the requirement to detect absorption by HCO+ with S/N of 10 in Milky Way high-velocity clouds. Based on the only existing measurement of HCO+ in HVCs, we expect a peak optical depth of tau=0.1, therefore for a 10-sigma detection, we require rms noise of 0.01 per 1 km/s channel.
The required per-channel Band 3 sensitivity (dS) is then a function of the background source continuum flux density at 3mm (S_3), and is given by dS = 0.01 * S_3. The observations have velocity resolution of 0.2 km/s per channel, which we anticipate to smooth to 1 km/s. Therefore, the final rms noise estimate is dS = 0.01 * S_3 * sqrt(1/0.2).

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose to search for molecular gas in the high-velocity clouds (HVCs) of the Milky Way halo. Our understanding of molecule formation and survival in the diffuse, dynamically-complex regime provided by HVCs is far from complete, and only a few detections of molecular gas exist within HVCs. Millimeter absorption line spectroscopy is an efficient and effective tool for detecting this material, and ALMA is uniquely suited to probe a wide range of HVC environments at high sensitivity. The proposed observations will allow us to understand molecule formation in interstellar conditions expected both locally and within galaxies at high redshift. In addition, the presence of molecules in HVCs will help to determine the influence of Galactic feedback and accretion on HVC formation, and will highlight their role of in the evolutionary history of the Milky Way.

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Wisconsin at Madison, University of

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Department of Astronomy, Wisconsin at Madison, University of
Astronomy and Space Science, Australia Telescope National Facility
